docs.title: Welcome
docs.text:
Welcome to the Tempo documentation.

Get started or go straight to the Tutorials

docs.title: What is Tempo?
docs.text:
Tempo is an Unreal Engine modding tool, that covers project management, automated builds, and more, built by Tempo-Organization.

  • Rapid development

    Speeds up your mod creation by streamlining various tasks.

  • Cross platform

    Tempo runs on Windows and Linux.

  • Project Management

    Organizes mods, builds, and configurations in one place.

  • Open Source

    Tempo is licensed under GPL3.

  • Compatibility

    Tempo supports all unreal engine 4 and 5 versions.

  • CI Friendly

    Integrates easily into automated build and CI pipelines.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Welcome to the Tempo FAQ. Here we try and answer any question that comes up frequently. If you can't find what you are looking for here, see our other help channels.

docs.title: What platforms does Tempo support?
docs.text: Currently we support Windows (x86-64 and i686) and Linux (x86-64 and aarch64).

docs.title: As a game developer, can I use this for my game's mod support?
docs.text: Yes, the license fully allows this, and we would love to see it.

docs.title: Can I use relative paths, in my tempo config?
docs.text: Yes, this is fully supported.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: All you need to get started making mods with Tempo.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Tempo runs on Windows and Linux.

  • Git
  • uv (later on, uv will not be needed for prebuilt executables)
  • Python 3.9.1 or later is needed only if you install from source via pip or pipx.
  • For prebuilt executables, Python is not required, but Git and uv are still needed.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Tempo is distributed as a single package, tempo-cli, which relies on tempo-core.

docs.title: Install `tempo-cli'
docs.text:
pippipxuv 
pip install git+https://www.github.com/tempo-cli

pipx install git+https://www.github.com/tempo-cli

uv add git+https://www.github.com/tempo-cli

docs.title: Prebuilt Releases
docs.text:
If you prefer prebuilt executables, downloads are available for Windows and Linux in the Releases section:

  • Windows: tempo_cli.exe
  • Linux: tempo_cli

docs.title: Adding to your PATH
docs.text:
To run the prebuilt executables from any terminal, you should add them to your system PATH:

WindowsLinux

Windows:

  1. Move tempo_cli.exe to a folder of your choice (e.g. C:\programs\tempo_cli).
  2. Open Settings → System → About → Advanced system settings → Environment Variables.
  3. Under System Variables, select Path and click Edit.
  4. Click New and add the folder path where tempo_cli.exe is located (e.g. C:\programs\tempo_cli).
  5. Click OK to save changes. Open a new Command Prompt to use tempo_cli from any directory.

Linux:

  1. Move tempo_cli to a folder of your choice (e.g., /usr/local/bin).
  2. Make sure it’s executable: 
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/tempo_cli
  1. If the folder isn’t already in your PATH, add it by editing your shell config file (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, etc.):
export PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/bin
  1. Reload your shell:
source ~/.bashrc

You can now run tempo_cli from any directory.

docs.title: Tempo CLI
docs.text:
There are a number of commands available which will aid you in building mods. Run the following for a list of the available commands:

tempo_cli --help

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text: See the help page for how to get help with Tempo, or to report bugs.

docs.title: Help
docs.text: If you need help with any aspect of Tempo, let us know! We would be happy to hear from you.

docs.title: Bugs and feature requests
docs.text: Report bugs via GitHub on the Tempo issues page. You can also post feature requests via GitHub issues, but see the Roadmap first.

docs.title: Help with using Tempo
docs.text: You can seek help with using Tempo in the discussion area on GitHub.

docs.title: Discord Server
docs.text: For more realtime feedback or chat, join our Discord server to connect with the Tempo community.

docs.title: Main CLI Commands
docs.text:
• cli command add to ini
  • cli command remove from ini
  • cli command add to text file
  • cli command remove from text file
  • cli command git stuff
  • cli command gen engine stuff
  • cli command open game dir
  • cli command open game paks dir
  • cli command open mod releases dir
  • cli command open dist dir
  • cli command open persistent mods dir
  • cli command open unreal auto mod dir
  • cli command open uproject dir
  • cli command open provided dir
  • cli command open provided file in default opener

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
• Create empty text file
  • Add new line to text file
  • Remove from text file by start, end, contains, etc.
  • Create new JSON file

docs.title: Installation / Setup
docs.text: • Add to PATH upon install from install sources

docs.title: Later Later
docs.text:
• Overridable colors, ability to disable coloring/progress bars/logging
  • Generate project files for uproject
  • Uproject, uplugin, engine ini edits for popular things (maybe also generic)
  • Default map change, game instance edits
  • Generate uproject from Win64 EXE (requires Unreal Engine version)
  • Unpack/repack game/mods
  • List game/mod contents
  • Logic for mod making to scan collection contents

docs.title: Later Later Later
docs.text:
• Automate installing from EGS
  • Mod Conflict Checker
  • Diff game and file list, backup diff (for cleanup/restore)
  • Layout support command
  • Engine pak making compression variants (defaults to compressed)
  • Switch to pathlib from strings

docs.title: Asset Automation
docs.text:
• Automate asset import for meshes/skeletons/textures/physics assets, PAL/DA, etc.
  • Handle various properties

docs.title: Hotkeys
docs.text:
• General hotkey functionality
  • Close game hotkey
  • Run script again hotkey
  • Bring Unreal Engine to front hotkey
  • Bring game to front hotkey
  • Close all hotkey (game, engine, and instances of Tempo)

docs.title: Docs & Examples
docs.text:
• GitHub Actions example with zipping files
  • Pre-commit example

docs.title: Configuration & Settings
docs.text:
• Expanded tokens for configuration (supports env vars, up a directory, path separator) References:
  • VS Code Variables Reference
  • VS Code Launch JSON Attributes
  • Fix it so all settings are loaded and saved from one place (currently several functions don’t follow this)
  • Add TOML support

docs.title: Config Types
docs.text:
• Workspace config
  • Project config
  • Mod-specific config
  • Game config
  • Config versions

  • Config

    Config Reference

  • Environment variables

    The environment variables reference shows how to customize Tempo environment variables.

    Environment Variables Reference

docs.title: Standard
docs.text:
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Init

    Init --> GenerateGameFileList : game installed and no file list
    Init --> DumpEntry : otherwise

    GenerateGameFileList --> DumpEntry

    %% Dumpers (all optional, loop back)
    DumpEntry --> DumpAESKeys
    DumpEntry --> DumpEngineVersion
    DumpEntry --> DumpScriptObjects
    DumpEntry --> DumpBuildConfiguration
    DumpEntry --> DumpJMap
    DumpEntry --> AddMod

    DumpAESKeys --> DumpEntry : optional
    DumpEngineVersion --> DumpEntry : optional
    DumpScriptObjects --> DumpEntry : optional
    DumpBuildConfiguration --> DumpEntry : optional
    DumpJMap --> DumpEntry : optional

    AddMod --> AddMod : add another mod
    AddMod --> UnrealEngineWork

    UnrealEngineWork --> TestModsAll

    TestModsAll --> CleanupPartial : optionally clean
    CleanupPartial --> TestModsAll
    CleanupPartial --> FullRunAll : mods ready

    TestModsAll --> FullRunAll : mods ready

    FullRunAll --> [*]

    %% States with readable labels
    state "file-io generate_game_file_list_json" as GenerateGameFileList
    state "dump aes_keys" as DumpAESKeys
    state "dump engine_version" as DumpEngineVersion
    state "dump script_objects" as DumpScriptObjects
    state "dump build_configuration" as DumpBuildConfiguration
    state "dump jmap" as DumpJMap
    state "mod add_mod" as AddMod
    state "Modding Work" as UnrealEngineWork
    state "run test_mods_all" as TestModsAll
    state "clean game" as CleanupPartial
    state "run full_run_all" as FullRunAll
    state "dump commands" as DumpEntry
